entry.title: Is Popper.js required for Bootstrap 4?
entry.content:
Several months ago I saw this question on StackOverflow:

I wanted to ask if Popper.js is absolutely necessary or not if I don‚Äôt use dropdown menus. Are there any other parts of Bootstrap 4 driven by Popper.js that would not work without the library?

I made a little research and posted my answer. I‚Äôm revisiting this now because from time to time I get upvotes and currently this is my highest voted answer. (I know, 15 upvotes is ridiculous if we compare it to posts of Stack Overflow ninjas, but I‚Äôm happy with it now. ü§ì) This blog post is here to spread the knowledge by mirroring my answer, and also to add some minor thoughts to it.

Which parts of Bootstrap 4 uses Popper.js?

To answer this part of the original question, the easiest we can do is to open the documentation and use its search box.

If we search for popper in Bootstrap 4‚Äôs documentation, the following results will come up:

Tooltips rely on the 3rd party library Popper.js for positioning.

Popovers rely on the 3rd party library Popper.js for positioning.

Dropdowns are built on a third party library, Popper.js, which provides dynamic positioning and viewport detection.

(These quotes are from the Beta documentation. Currently the phrasing is different but the results are the same.)

So these are the Bootstrap 4 components that need Popper.js:

  • dropdowns
  • popovers
  • tooltips

(According to my answer on StackOverflow, Bootstrap 4 Beta needed Popper.js for modals as well, which is not true for the current 4.3.1 version.)

Do I need Popper.js if I don‚Äôt use these components?

Popper.js is stated as required in the documentation:

Many of our components require the use of JavaScript to function. Specifically, they require jQuery, Popper.js, and our own JavaScript plugins. Place the following scripts near the end of your pages, right before the closing </body> tag, to enable them. jQuery must come first, then Popper.js, and then our JavaScript plugins.

And Bootstrap 4 JS (Beta version at least) logs an error if it can‚Äôt find Popper.js:

Uncaught Error: Bootstrap dropdown require Popper.js (https://popper.js.org)
    at bootstrap.min.js:6
    at bootstrap.min.js:6
    at bootstrap.min.js:6

However, Bootstrap 4 can be used without Popper.js, if we don‚Äôt use tooltips, popovers nor dropdowns. For example, navbar‚Äôs JS functionality (mobile menu on the right) works well without Popper.js.

‚Ä¶but there‚Äôs a bundle!

More answers on the same topic mentions that there‚Äôs a bundle version of Bootstrap 4 JS, which includes Popper.js, therefore there‚Äôs no need to bother including Popper.js by hand.

In my opinion, or at least for me, the whole point of not importing Popper.js is to reduce loading time of a webpage by importing only what is required. In this case, the bundle doesn‚Äôt help.

‚Ä¶de h√°t van bundle!

T√∂bb v√°lasz is eml√≠ti a sz√≥ban forg√≥ k√©rd√©s alatt, hogy a Bootstrap 4-nek van egy bundle verzi√≥ja, ami tartalmazza a Popper.js-t, teh√°t nem kell g√∂rcs√∂lni a Popper.js k√©zzel import√°l√°s√°n.

Az √©n v√©lem√©nyem viszont az, vagy legal√°bbis sz√°momra a k√©rd√©snek pont az az √©rtelme, hogy az√©rt nem import√°ljuk a Popper.js-t, mert cs√∂kkenteni szeretn√©nk a weboldalunk bet√∂lt√©si idej√©t azzal, hogy csak a sz√ºks√©ges dolgokat import√°ljuk. Legal√°bbis majdnem. Ugyanis az intervallum alul nyitott, az ‚ÄúInitial commit‚Äù kimaradt. Ezt explicit m√≥don kell majd ki√≠ratnom a changelog v√©g√©re:

K√∂zt√ºk a commit-ok pedig felsorol√°sok. Ut√≥bbihoz a --oneline helyett saj√°t form√°tumot kell megadni a git log-nak:

√ârtelmes alternat√≠v√°nak a Gitea-t tal√°ltam, ami a Gogs forkja, picivel t√∂bb funkci√≥val √©s nyitottabb open-source felfog√°ssal. Eleve √∫gy van tervezve √©s fejlesztve, hogy gyeng√©bb g√©peken, ARM architekt√∫r√°n √©s pl. Raspberry Pi-n is haszn√°lhat√≥ legyen.

Telep√≠t√©s

Meglep≈ë m√≥don nincs hozz√° Debian csomag, a Docker image pedig nem fut ARM-en.

Szerencs√©re a Gitea-t fejleszt≈ë csapat egy csom√≥ f√©le rendszerre elk√©sz√≠ti a bin√°risokat, melyek a honlapjukr√≥l √©s GitHub-r√≥l is let√∂lthet≈ëek. √âs van k√∂zt√ºk ARM-re ford√≠tott bin√°ris, t√∂bb is, nekem Raspberry Pi 3B+-ra a gitea-1.5.3-linux-arm-7 verzi√≥ kellett. Ezekben a f√°jlokban minden sz√ºks√©ges dolog megvan, csak futtatni kell ≈ëket.

√ârdemes neki l√©trehozni egy j√∫zert √©s az al√≥l futtatni a programot:

sudo adduser gitea
sudo su - gitea
wget https://dl.gitea.io/gitea/1.5.3/gitea-1.5.3-linux-arm-7 -O gitea
chmod u+x ./gitea
./gitea web --port 3000

A Gitea-nek kelleni fog egy adatb√°zis. Tud SQLite-ot is haszn√°lni (1 db adatf√°jlt jelent), de ha pl. MySQL-be vagy Postgres-be szeretn√©d t√°rolni az adatokat, akkor √©rdemes el≈ëbb el≈ëk√©sz√≠teni azt, miel≈ëtt a gitea bin√°rist elind√≠tod. √ân a teszthez maradtam az SQLite-n√°l.

Kezdeti be√°ll√≠t√°sok

Ha a fenti paranccsal elind√≠tjuk a Gitea-t, elindul a szerver √©s a b√∂ng√©sz≈ënkben a http://localhost:3000/ URL-en el√©rj√ºk a f≈ëoldalt. Ha b√°rmelyik linkre r√°kattintunk, a telep√≠t≈ë k√©perny≈ë fog bej√∂nni, ahol n√©h√°ny kezdeti be√°ll√≠t√°st megadhatunk, pl:

  • app neve (c√≠msorban megjelen≈ë sz√∂veg)
  • adatb√°zis kapcsol√≥d√°si adatok
  • √∫tvonalak

A fentiek ellen≈ërz√©s√©n/m√≥dos√≠t√°s√°n k√≠v√ºl amit fontosnak tartok, az a ment√©s gomb feletti egyik lenyithat√≥ szekci√≥ban megb√∫v√≥ admin account be√°ll√≠t√°s. √ârdemes itt megadni az adminisztr√°tor felhaszn√°l√≥ adatait, pl√°ne, ha letiltod a regisztr√°ci√≥t. Egy√©bk√©nt az els≈ë regisztr√°lt j√∫zer lesz az adminisztr√°tor.

Amikor ezt az ≈±rlapot leok√©zzuk, a Gitea 1-2 percig (legal√°bbis Pi-n) elmolyol a mapp√°k, konfigf√°jlok √©s adatb√°zist√°bl√°k l√©trehoz√°s√°val, ut√°na bej√∂n a login k√©perny≈ë √©s kezdhet√ºnk vele j√°tszani.

A megadott be√°ll√≠t√°sok √©s m√©g rengeteg param√©ter k√©s≈ëbb is m√≥dos√≠that√≥ a konfigf√°jlban (custom/conf/app.ini). Miel≈ëtt komolyabban elkezden√©nk haszn√°lni a Gitea-t, √©rdemes v√©gigolvasni az √∂sszes be√°ll√≠t√°si lehet≈ës√©get.

Tapasztalatok (gyors kipr√≥b√°l√°s)

A HTTP clone/push gy√∂ny√∂r≈±en m≈±k√∂dik a webes fel√ºlet user+pass komb√≥j√°val. Az SSH m√≥dszern√©l a clone URL gener√°l√°s nem az igazi, a Git rep√≥k mapp√°j√°t lehagyja az URL-b≈ël, viszont a saj√°t be√©p√≠tett SSH szerver√©vel frank√≥n megy ez is. A webes fel√ºleten a profil be√°ll√≠t√°sain√°l fel lehet t√∂lteni SSH/RSA publikus kulcsot.

Megl√©v≈ë rep√≥k import√°l√°sa is pofon egyszer≈±, ez nekem nagyon fontos volt. Persze √≥r√°kig k√≠s√©rleteztem vele, mire r√°j√∂ttem a nyitj√°ra - err≈ël k√ºl√∂n posztban √≠rok.

A webes fel√ºletet √©s funkci√≥kat tekintve gyakorlatilag egy GitHub kl√≥nt kapunk. (Issues, PR, issue/pr templates, organizations, teams, etc.)

Konfig

√ân az al√°bbiakat adtam hozz√° k√©zzel a telep√≠t≈ë √°ltal kik√∂p√∂tt konfig f√°jlhoz. Ez nyilv√°n nem lesz mindenkinek megfelel≈ë, √≠zel√≠t≈ëk√©nt, illetve saj√°t feljegyz√©sk√©nt (note to self) teszem ide.

[repository]
DEFAULT_PRIVATE = true
FORCE_PRIVATE = true

[security]
DISABLE_GIT_HOOKS = true
IMPORT_LOCAL_PATHS = true

[server]
DISABLE_ROUTER_LOG = true
START_SSH_SERVER = true
SSH_PORT = 2222

[service]
DISABLE_REGISTRATION = true
REQUIRE_SIGNIN_VIEW = true

Telep√≠t√©s service-k√©nt (systemd)

Miut√°n megbizonyosodtam r√≥la, hogy j√≥ lesz ez a cucc, be√°ll√≠tottam service-k√©nt, hogy induljon a g√©ppel automatikusan. L√©trehoztam egy gitea.service f√°jlt az al√°bbi tartalommal:

[Unit]
Description=Gitea
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=gitea
Group=gitea
WorkingDirectory=/home/gitea
ExecStart=/home/gitea/gitea web --port 3000
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Majd az al√°bbi parancsokkal telep√≠tettem √©s elind√≠tottam:

systemctl enable /home/gitea/gitea.service
service gitea start

entry.title: Free contact form using Basin
entry.content:
My previous post was about free contact form solutions that can send email. I tried out Basin which was before my gold medal winner based on its website only. Here are my experiences. üôÇ

First steps

The sign up page is minimal, it only asks for my email address and my new password. Of course, email address needs to be confirmed before I can login.

After logging in, the dashboard is displayed. Before I created my form, I checked what‚Äôs inside Account settings. Besides the email address and password change, there‚Äôs only a button for complete removal.

At form creation, it asks 2 things: the name of the form (displayed on the dashboard), and the redirect URL where visitors will be sent after filling out the form. If we leave it blank, Basin will show its own page as a default.

After I created my form, it was opened in the interface with an empty Submissions panel. There I already saw that incoming submissions can be filtered, deleted and marked as spam.

Setup tabs shows HTML code snippets which helps to implement the form on a website just by copy-pasting. There are snippets for both the clickable and the invisible Google captcha.

Edit tab provides additional settings of the form:

  • multiple whitelisted domains can be specified, from where form submissions are allowed
  • required captcha can be turned on
  • and also there‚Äôs an opportunity to send GDPR compliant data receipt to the sender

On the Email tab, the target email address can be modified, where form data should be sent. It‚Äôs the registered email address by default. Also, there are options to specify CC and custom sender name (instead of ‚ÄúBasin‚Äù), and subject is editable too. Subject is the form‚Äôs name + ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve received a submission‚Äù by default.

Testing

I turned on captcha and receipt sending and implemented the form with the invisible captcha. It‚Äôs super cool that I can test it from localhost. I submitted the form and it correctly redirected to my URL. The email arrived a few seconds later to my address. The email is formatted nicely and contains every important detail:

Reply-to is working properly too, I can answer to the email address typed in the form with a single click.

An email arrived also to the address I typed in the form. It tells what data I sent to where, and it provides a button where a data removal request can be filed:

Submitted information appeared also on the Submissions tab as expected. Looking further, there‚Äôs the Export tab where I can download form submissions in CSV or JSON using an API key. Finally, Zapier connection can be set up on the Integrations tab, but I didn‚Äôt do this, I reached my goal.

Basin deserves my gold prize. It‚Äôs a professional, easy-to-use, user friendly, GDPR-ready, free service. üèÜ

This is what I was looking for.

Addition

A little addition is needed for Google reCAPTCHA to work properly. Code snippet provided by Basin works in a way that submit button‚Äôs click event is handled by reCAPTCHA and it submits the form immediately. This is a problem when you need form validation, either natively or via a JS library. I found a solution here:

<form id="invisible-recaptcha-form" accept-charset="UTF-8" action="https://usebasin.com/f/..." method="POST">

	<!-- input fields -->

	<div class="g-recaptcha" data-sitekey="..." data-callback="onSubmit" data-badge="inline" data-size="invisible"></div>
	<button class="btn btn-primary">Submit</button>
</form>
<script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js" async defer></script>
<script>
	document.getElementById("invisible-recaptcha-form").addEventListener("submit", function(){
		event.preventDefault();
		grecaptcha.reset();
		grecaptcha.execute();
	}, false);
	function onSubmit(token) {
		document.getElementById("invisible-recaptcha-form").submit();
	}
</script>

What did I do to Basin‚Äôs snippet:

  • Removed g-recaptcha class from submit button, and placed it on a new <div> element.
  • Moved data-* attributes too from the button to the new element, and added a new one: data-size="invisible".
  • I added an event handler to the script, which is triggered on form submit and calls the captcha.

When the user hits the submit button:

  • The browser‚Äôs native validation will run first.
  • Then the event handler initializes the captcha.
  • Captcha inserts response in the form, and calls the callback, which submits the form.
